{{About|the parent company to M. Arthur Gensler Jr. & Associates, Inc.||Gensler (disambiguation)}} {{Use mdy dates|date=January 2016}} {{Infobox company | name = Gensler | logo = Gensler logo.svg | logo_size = 200px | image = | image_caption = | type = [[Private Company|Private]] | traded_as = | founded = {{start date|1965}}
[[San Francisco]], [[California]], [[United States of America|U.S.]] | area_served = Worldwide | key_people = {{plainlist| * Andy Cohen, Co-CEO * Diane Hoskins, Co-CEO }} | industry = [[Architecture]] | products = | services = {{plainlist| * [[Architecture]] * [[Branding agency|Brand Design]] * [[Consulting & Real Estate]] * [[Digital Experience Design]] * [[Interior Design]] * [[Sustainability]] * [[Urban design|Urban Strategies & Design]] }}{{cite web|url=http://www.gensler.com/about/services|title=Gensler Services}} | revenue = US$1.2 billion (2018){{cite web|url=https://www.gensler.com/uploads/document/355/file/Gensler_Fact_Sheet_10223018.pdf|title=Gensler revenue}} | num_employees = 6,000+ (as of 2018){{cite web| work=[[Chief Executive]]| title=Gensler Size| accessdate=November 8, 2018| url=https://chiefexecutive.net/gensler-co-ceos-bring-an-architects-mindset-to-the-corner-office/}} | homepage = {{URL|https://www.gensler.com}} | founders = {{plainlist| * M. Arthur Gensler Jr. * Drue Gensler * James Follett }} | location_city = [[San Francisco]], [[California]] | location_country = [[United States of America|U.S.]] | locations = 48 offices in 16 countries{{cite web|url=http://www.gensler.com/offices|title=Gensler offices}} }} '''M. Arthur Gensler Jr. & Associates, Inc.''', referred to as '''Gensler''', is an [[United States of America|American]] [[design firm|design]] and [[architecture firm]] headquartered in [[San Francisco]], [[California]].{{cite news| newspaper=[[The Washington Post]]| title=Gensler, with Robert Peck on board, expanding consulting practice| last=O'Connell| first=Jonathan| date=August 26, 2012| url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/capitalbusiness/gensler-with-robert-peck-on-board-expanding-consulting-practice/2012/08/24/d0b30750-ebdc-11e1-a80b-9f898562d010_story.html| accessdate=July 7, 2014}}{{cite web| url=http://www.hoovers.com/company/M_Arthur_Gensler_Jr__Associates__Inc/rfcjjsi-1.html| title=M. Arthur Gensler Jr. & Associates, Inc.| publisher=[[Hoover's]]| accessdate=September 22, 2012}} In 2015, Gensler generated $1.18 billion in revenue, the most of any architecture firm based in the [[United States of America|United States]].{{cite news|url=http://www.architecturalrecord.com/Top300/2016-Top-300-Architecture-Firms-1|title=Top 300 Architecture Firms|last=|first=|date=June 2016|work=[[Architectural Record]]|accessdate=November 13, 2016}} As of 2015, it operated offices in 46 cities in 16 countries worldwide.{{cite news| first=Ben| last=Ikenson| title=Gensler's Secret Sauce| work=[[Metropolis (architecture magazine)|Metropolis]]| date=July 2013| url=http://www.metropolismag.com/June-2013/Genslers-Secret-Sauce/| accessdate=July 7, 2014}} ==Founding== [[Art Gensler]], along with his wife Drue Gensler acting as office manager, and their associate, James Follett, founded the firm in 1965.{{cite journal| first=Robert| last=Cassidy| title=Art Gensler: Still Making a Difference for Clients Every Day| work=Building Design+Construction| date=January 3, 2012| url=http://www.bdcnetwork.com/art-gensler-still-making-difference-clients-every-day| accessdate=July 7, 2014}} The firm originally focused on corporate interiors, but has since diversified into numerous forms of architecture and design, including commercial office buildings, retail centers, airports, education facilities, and entertainment complexes. It is also involved in planning and urban design, brand strategy, environmental graphic design, mission-critical facilities, sustainable design consulting, and other areas.{{cite web| publisher=Gensler| title=About Gensler| accessdate=July 7, 2014| url=http://www.gensler.com/uploads/documents/About_Gensler_Fact_Sheet_130801_08_01_2013.pdf}} ==Staff== As of 2018, the firm employed more than 5,500 people working in 46 offices in 16 countries. Gensler's newest office is in Portland, Oregon, which was opened in 2018. ==Recognition== Gensler was awarded the [[Architecture Firm Award]] in 2000 by the [[American Institute of Architects]].{{cite news| work=Architecture Week| title=Gensler Wins AIA Firm Award |date=June 7, 2000| url=http://www.architectureweek.com/2000/0607/news_5-1.html| accessdate=July 7, 2014}} In 2015, Gensler was awarded for their proposed London Underline project.{{cite web | url=http://www.londonplanningawards.com/index.php/press-releases | title=Temples and tunnels among winners of top planning awards | publisher=London Planning Awards}} Founder Art Gensler received a [[Lifetime Achievement Award]] from the [[Design Futures Council]] in 2016.{{cite web|title=Art Gensler Receives Lifetime Achievement Award from the Design Futures Council|url=http://www.di.net/news/art-gensler-dfc-lifetime-achievement/|website=Design Intelligence|publisher=Design Futures Council|accessdate=23 January 2016}} ==Notable projects== ===Built=== *[[John F. Kennedy International Airport]], [[New York City]], NY, [[TWA Flight Center|JetBlue T5]]{{cite news| title=JetBlue's New Terminal at JFK Offers Huge Capacity, No Charm | url=https://www.bloomberg.com/apps/news?pid=newsarchive&sid=axmSwa9nOhKU| publisher=[[Bloomberg News]]| date=October 22, 2008| accessdate=July 7, 2014| last=Russell| first=James S.}} *[[Ritz-Carlton Hotel Company|Ritz-Carlton Hotel]], [[Dubai International Financial Centre]],{{cite web| title=Abu Dhabi Financial Centre| url=http://www.gensler.com/projects/abu-dhabi-financial-centre?l=featured&s=title| publisher=Genzler| accessdate=July 7, 2014}} [[Dubai]], [[United Arab Emirates]], 2004 *[[Houston Ballet Center for Dance]],{{cite news| title=Houston Ballet's home points city to Theater District| url=http://www.chron.com/news/houston-texas/article/Houston-Ballet-s-home-points-city-to-Theater-1686096.php| last=Glentzer| first=Molly| work=[[Houston Chronicle]]| date=April 8, 2011| accessdate=July 7, 2014}} Houston, Texas, 2011 *[[San Francisco International Airport]], [[San Francisco]], [[California|CA]], T2 terminal,{{cite web| title=San Francisco International Airport, Terminal 2| url=http://www.gensler.com/projects/san-francisco-international-airport-terminal-2?l=featured&s=title| publisher=Genzler| accessdate=July 7, 2014}} 2011 *[[The Avenues (Kuwait)|The Avenues, Phase III]],{{cite web| title=The Avenues - Phase III| url=http://www.gensler.com/projects/the-avenues-phase-iii?l=featured&s=title| publisher=Genzler| accessdate=July 7, 2014}} Kuwait City, [[Kuwait]], 2012 *[[Facebook, Inc.]],{{cite web| first=Devina| last=Divecha| url=http://www.constructionweekonline.com/article-13428-gensler-to-design-facebooks-london-office/| title=Gensler to design Facebook's London office| publisher=ConstructionWeekOnline.com |date=August 1, 2011| accessdate=July 7, 2014}} [[London]], 2012 *[[Duke Kunshan University]],{{cite web| title=Duke Kunshan University| url=http://www.gensler.com/projects/duke-kunshan-university?l=featured&s=title| publisher=Genzler| accessdate=July 7, 2014}} [[Kunshan]], [[China]], 2013 *[[Shanghai Tower]],{{cite web| title=Shanghai Tower| url=http://www.gensler.com/projects/shanghai-tower?l=featured&s=title| publisher=Genzler| accessdate=July 7, 2014}} [[Shanghai]], [[China]], 2014 *[[Tower at PNC Plaza]],{{cite web| title=Tower at PNC Plaza| url=http://www.gensler.com/projects/the-tower-at-pnc-plaza?l=featured&s=title| publisher=Genzler| accessdate=July 7, 2014}} [[Pittsburgh]], [[Pennsylvania]], 2014 *[[Dallas Mavericks]]' locker room at American Airlines Arena, [[Dallas,Texas|Dallas, Texas]] 2017{{Cite web|url=https://www.dmagazine.com/publications/d-ceo/2018/january-february/dallas-workspaces-offices-digital-technology-startups/|title=Dallas Workspaces Are Going Digital|website=D Magazine|access-date=2018-01-22}} *[[Banc of California Stadium]]- [[Los Angeles, California]], 2018 File:JFKNewYorkTerm4 1.jpg|[[John F. Kennedy International Airport|JFK Airport Terminal 4]], [[New York City]] File:HoustonBalletApril92011.jpg|[[Houston Ballet|Houston Ballet Centre for Dance]], [[Houston]] File:Shanghai Tower 2015.jpg|[[Shanghai Tower]], [[Shanghai]] File:Tower at PNC Plaza as seen at Fifth at Wood in 2016.jpg|[[Tower at PNC Plaza]], [[Pittsburgh]] File:SFO T2 Gensler EntryHall.jpg|[[San Francisco International Airport|SF Airport T2 Entry-hall]], [[San Francisco]] ===Unbuilt=== *[[Farmers Field (Los Angeles)|Farmers Field]],{{cite web| title=Farmers Field| url=http://www.gensler.com/projects/farmers-field| publisher=Genzler| accessdate=July 7, 2014}} [[Los Angeles]], [[California]], 2014 ==References== {{reflist}} ==Further reading== *{{Cite news|last=McKee|first=Bradford|date=March 2005|title=Art Gensler: The Boss|periodical=Architecture|publisher=BPI Communications, Inc.|volume=89|issue=5|page=127}} *{{cite web| publisher=AIACC| title=Arthur Gensler - AIACC Lifetime Achievement Award| accessdate=December 29, 2016| url=http://www.aiacc.org/wp-content/uploads/2016/04/LA16-004.pdf}} *{{cite web| title=Art Gensler proud of design, largest architect firm in world| accessdate=December 29, 2016| url=http://www.sfgate.com/bayarea/article/Art-Gensler-proud-of-design-largest-architect-5321208.php}} ==External links== *{{Official website|http://www.gensler.com}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Gensler}} [[Category:Architecture firms based in California]] [[Category:Companies based in San Francisco]] [[Category:Design companies established in 1965]] [[Category:American companies established in 1965]] [[Category:Architecture in the San Francisco Bay Area]] [[Category:Gensler buildings]] [[Category:1965 establishments in California]] [[Category:1965 in San Francisco]] [[Category:Prix Versailles-winning architects and designers]]

{{no footnotes|date=April 2017}} [[File:Gyula Benczúr - Self-portrait.jpg|thumb|215px|Self-portrait (1917)]] '''Gyula Benczúr''' (28 January 1844, [[Nyíregyháza]] - 16 July 1920, [[Szécsény]]) was a [[List of Hungarian painters|Hungarian painter]] and art teacher. He specialized in portraits and historical scenes.
==Biography== His family moved to [[Košice|Kassa]] when he was still very young and he displayed an early talent for drawing. He began his studies in 1861 with [[Hermann Anschutz]] and Johann Georg Hiltensperger (1806-1890). From 1865 to 1869, he studied with [[Karl von Piloty]].
He achieved international success in 1870 when he won the Hungarian national competition for historical painting with his depiction of King Stephen's baptism. He then assisted Piloty with the [[fresco]]es at the [[Maximilianeum]] and the [[Rathaus]] in [[Munich]] and illustrated books by the great German writer, [[Friedrich Schiller]]. King [[Ludwig II of Bavaria|Ludwig II]] of Bavaria gave him several commissions.
He was named a Professor at the [[Academy of Fine Arts, Munich]], in 1875. Soon after, he built a home in Ambach on [[Lake Starnberg]]; designed by his brother Béla. In 1883, he returned to Hungary, where he continued to be an art teacher. One of his most distinguished pupils was the Swiss-born American painter [[Adolfo Müller-Ury]]. Benczúr was later a favorite among the Hungarian upper-class, painting numerous portraits of kings and aristocrats. He also created some religious works; notably altarpieces for [[St. Stephen's Basilica]] and [[Buda Castle]].
He was an honorary member of the [[Hungarian Academy of Sciences]]. Streets have been named after him in [[Balassagyarmat]], [[Balatonkenese]], [[Berettyóújfalu]], [[Bonyhád]], Budapest, [[Debrecen]], [[Jászberény]], [[Komló]], [[Pécs]], [[Szabadszállás]], [[Szeged]] and Košice. His daughters Olga (1875-1962) and Ida (1876-1970) also became well-known artists.
==Selected paintings== <gallery mode="packed" heights="165"> File:Benczur-narcissus.jpg|[[Narcissus (mythology)|Narcissus]] File:Benczur-hunyadi laszlo bucsuja.jpg|[[Ladislaus Hunyadi]]'s Farewell File:Benczúr Olvasó nő.jpg|Reading in the Woods File:Benczur-vajk.jpg|The Baptism of [[Stephen I of Hungary|Stephen I]] File:Benczur-kleopatra.jpg|[[Cleopatra]] </gallery>
==Sources== *''Gyula Benczúr, Exposition Memoriale''. Budapest: [[Hungarian National Museum]], 1958 * Gábor Ö. Pogány,. ''Nineteenth Century Hungarian Painting'', (1958) Reprint, Budapest: Corvina Press, 1972 *Katalin Telepy, ''Benczúr''. Nyíregyháza, Hungary: Jósa András Múzeum, 1963 *Antal Kampis, ''The History of Art in Hungary''. Budapest: Corvina Press, 1966
==External links== {{commonscat|Gyula Benczúr}} *[http://www.hung-art.hu/frames-e.html?/english/b/benczur/muvek/index.html Works and biography of Gyula Benczúr @ Fine arts in Hungary] *[http://www.webumenia.sk/web/guest/search/-/simpleSearch//query=au%3A%22Gyula+Bencz%C3%BAr%22 Works of Gyula Benczúr held in Slovak art collections]
{{Authority control}}

revision.comment: +{{[[Template:Authority control|Authority control]]}} (3 sources from Wikidata), [[WP:GenFixes]] on, using [[Project:AWB|AWB]]
revision.text: {{Blacklisted-links|1= *https://learningmojo.files.wordpress.com/2014/10/jerwood-prize-finalists-catalogue.pdf *:''Triggered by \bfiles\.wordpress\.com\b on the global blacklist''|bot=Cyberbot II|invisible=false}} {{Infobox artist | name = Jonathan Huxley | image = | image_size = | alt = Image of Huxley working on his collaborative installation "A Boys Own Story" | caption = Huxley working at the [[Royal Academy]] on his collaborative installation "A Boys Own Story". | birth_date = {{birth date |1965|11|10||mf=y}} | birth_place = [[Surrey]], UK | nationality = British | training = [[Berkshire College of Art and Design]], [[Nottingham Trent Polytechnic]], [[Royal Academy of Arts]], | known_for = [[fine art]], [[murals]], [[public art]] | awards = [[Royal Academy]] Young Masters Prize 1992 | religion = | footnotes = | spouse = | children = }} '''Jonathan Huxley''' (born 1965) is a British artist whose paintings and murals depict illusions of human figures in motion. ==Education== Huxley was born in [[Surrey]] in 1965. He studied at [[Berkshire College of Art and Design]] (1985–1986) and [[Nottingham Trent Polytechnic]] (1986–1989) and graduated from the latter with a BA (Hons) in Fine Art in 1989. He studied for a Diploma in Fine Art at the [[Royal Academy of Arts]] (1989–1992). ==Professional life== Huxley's work is featured by Galerie Olivier Waltman[http://www.galeriewaltman.com/Jonathan_Huxley.html Huxley entry, Galerie Olivier Waltman] in Paris, the Crane Kalman Gallery[http://www.cranekalman.com/artist/jonathan-huxley Huxley entry, Crane Kalman Gallery] in London and Waltman Ortega Fine Art[http://www.waltmanortega.com/Jonathan_Huxley.html Huxley entry, Waltman Ortega Fine Art] in Miami. Notable works include a 1993 large scale mural commissioned by [[Bermondsey Council]] and a mural in the Met Bar in the Metropolitan Hotel, Park Lane London.[http://www.justluxe.com/travel/london-news__1244911.php New Cocktail Recipes Debut at The Met Bar London, Carol Driver, Jan. 10th, 2011] Huxley has also been commissioned byWho's Who in Art, 36th Edition, Morven Press, 2015. [[UBS]], [[Goldman Sachs]], [[Barclays]], [[EMI]], the [[Richard Rogers]] headquarters for [[Channel Four Television Corporation]] and [[The Colmore Building]] in Birmingham. Huxley suffers from the [[visual impairment]] conditions [[nystagmus]] and [[photophobia]] and this has influenced his approach to creating art.[http://www.waltmanortega.com/artist_statement_Jonathan_Huxley.html Huxley artist statement, Waltman Ortega Fine Art][https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=1a6zu1KgG1w Huxley talks about installation "A Boys Own Story"] Since 2007 Huxley has been Artist Educator at the Royal Academy of Arts. New work by Huxley was showcased at the 2017 [[London Art Fair]] by Crane Kalman Gallery.[http://www.londonartfair.co.uk/galleries/crane-kalman-gallery/ Huxley at London Art Fair 2017] ==Awards and distinctions== Huxley was awarded the Royal Academy Young Masters Prize in 1992 and the award for the most popular painting at the Royal College of Art show in 1997. He was featured in a 1991 documentary for [[Channel 4]] 'Behind the Eye'.[http://artsonfilm.wmin.ac.uk/films.php?a=view&recid=221 Arts on Film entry for "Behind the Eye" by John Davies] Huxley was elected a member of the [[Royal Watercolour Society]] in 2014.[http://www.royalwatercoloursociety.co.uk/artists/72-jonathan-huxley/biography/ Huxley entry at RWS] He was a prizewinner in the 2009 [[RWS/Sunday Times Watercolour Competition]],[http://www.culture24.org.uk/art/art71417 RWS/Sunday Times Watercolour Competition] winning the Penguin Classics Prize for Cover Art, and was a finalist for the 2014 [[Jerwood Drawing Prize]].[https://learningmojo.files.wordpress.com/2014/10/jerwood-prize-finalists-catalogue.pdf Jerwood Drawing Prize finalists catalogue 2014] He was featured in the Autumn 2016 issue of the [[Bankside Gallery]] RWS magazine. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://jonathanhuxley.com/ Jonathan Huxley official website] {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Huxley, Jonahan}} [[Category:1965 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:British artists]] [[Category:Alumni of Nottingham Trent University]] [[Category:Alumni of the Royal Academy Schools]] [[Category:Artists with disabilities]] [[Category:English people with disabilities]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=February 2014}} {{Use British English|date=February 2014}} {{Infobox architectural practice | name = Kelly & Birchall | image = St Patrick Church Soho Square 4 June 2011.JPG | caption = [[St Patrick's Church, Soho Square]], central London, built by Kelly & Birchall in 1891–93 | architects = John Kelly
Edward Birchall | partners = | city = [[Leeds]] | coordinates = | founded = 1886 | dissolved = 1904 | awards = | significant_buildings = [[St Patrick's Church, Soho Square]] ([[Listed building|Grade II* listed]]); [[St Luke's Church, Kingston upon Thames]] (Grade II listed) | significant_projects = | significant_design = }} '''Kelly & Birchall''', a partnership between '''Edward Birchall''' (1839–6 March 1903){{cite web | url=http://www.scottisharchitects.org.uk/architect_full.php?id=206154 | title=Edward Birchall | work=[[Dictionary of Scottish Architects]] | accessdate=19 April 2013}} and '''John Kelly''' (1840–1904),{{cite web | url=http://www.scottisharchitects.org.uk/architect_full.php?id=206755 | title=John Kelly | work=[[Dictionary of Scottish Architects]] | accessdate=19 April 2013}} was an [[architectural practice]] based in [[Leeds]], England, from 1886 to 1904{{cite web | url=http://www.scottisharchitects.org.uk/architect_full.php?id=206754 | title=Kelly & Birchall | work=[[Dictionary of Scottish Architects]] | accessdate=19 April 2013}} and specialising in churches in the [[Italianate architecture|Italianate]] and [[Gothic Revival architecture|Gothic Revival]] styles. ==Works== The partnership between Edward Birchall, who had practised in Leeds since the early 1860s, and John Kelly, who had previously been in partnership with Richard Life Adams (1840–83), was established in 1886.{{cite web | url=http://www.victorianweb.org/art/architecture/leeds/13.html | title=Former Church Institute, corner of Albion Place and Lands Lane | work=The Victorian Web | date= 14 March 2012|accessdate=27 May 2015}} The church of St Mary of Bethany, [[New Wortley]], Leeds was one of Kelly & Birchall's earliest projects. Initially worked on by [[Adams & Kelly]], Kelly & Birchall took it to completion. Built in 1885 at a cost of £5,600, it featured a [[spire]] of 135 feet and a brick-lined interior. St Mary of Bethany was demolished in 1975.{{cite web |url=http://www.leodis.net/display.aspx?resourceIdentifier=2003520_14544314| title=St Mary of Bethany Church, demolition |work=Leodis – a photographic archive of Leeds |accessdate=4 November 2014}} Two more of Kelly & Birchall's Leeds buildings have also since been demolished. The original All Hallows Church, on the corner of Hyde Park Road and Regent Terrace, Leeds, built in 1876 at an estimated cost of £10,585, was destroyed by fire on 27 April 1970, though the [[vicarage]] remains.{{cite web |url=http://allhallowsleeds.org/about/history/|title=History|publisher=All Hallows Church, Leeds |accessdate=5 December 2015}} The Roman Catholic church of St Francis of Assisi, Manor Road, [[Holbeck]], built in 1896, was closed and demolished in 1979.{{cite web|url=http://services.english-heritage.org.uk/ResearchReportsPdfs/020_2008WEB.pdf |title=religion and place in Leeds – A Survey and Gazetteer of Places of Worship 1900–2005 |first=John |last=Minnis |publisher=[[English Heritage]] |year=2008 |issn=1749-8775 |accessdate=27 February 2014 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120323162640/http://services.english-heritage.org.uk/ResearchReportsPdfs/020_2008WEB.pdf |archivedate=23 March 2012 |df= }} Kelly & Birchall designed the [[Listed building|Grade II listed]] [[St Luke's Church, Kingston upon Thames|St Luke's Church]] on Gibbon Road in [[Kingston upon Thames]], built between 1886 and 1887{{cite book | title=[[The Buildings of England]] – London 2: South | publisher=[[Penguin Books]] | author=[[Bridget Cherry|Cherry, Bridget]] and [[Nikolaus Pevsner|Pevsner, Nikolaus]] | year=1983 | location=London | page=313 | isbn=0-14-0710-47-7}} and the Grade II* listed [[St Patrick's Church, Soho Square]] (a [[Roman Catholic]] church in central London), built between 1891 and 1893.{{cite book | title=[[The Buildings of England]] – London 1: The Cities of London and Westminster (third edition) | publisher=[[Penguin Books]] | author= [[Bridget Cherry|Cherry, Bridget]] and [[Nikolaus Pevsner|Pevsner, Nikolaus]]| year=1973 | location=London | page=514 | isbn=0-14-0710-12-4}}{{cite web |url=http://taking-stock.org.uk/Home/Dioceses/Archdiocese-of-Westminster/St-Patrick-Soho|title=St Patrick – Soho |work=Taking Stock: Catholic Churches of England & Wales|accessdate=27 May 2015}} In Leeds they also designed the Central Higher Grade School{{cite web | url=http://www.scottisharchitects.org.uk/building_full.php?id=233831 | title=Central Higher Grade School | work=[[Dictionary of Scottish Architects]] | accessdate=28 February 2014}} (later known as Leeds Higher Grade School){{cite book | url={{Google books|XHJaiPxJ_6QC|Pevsner Architectural Guides: Leeds|page=154|plainurl=yes}}|title=Pevsner Architectural Guides: Leeds | publisher=[[Yale University Press]] | author=Wrathmell, Susan (ed.) | year=2005 | location=New Haven and London | pages=29 and 153–4 | isbn=0-300-10736-6}} in Woodhouse Lane; this was built in 1889, with an [[attic]] added in 1890 by William Landless, who had been [[clerk of works]] at Kelly & Birchall, executing designs on their behalf.{{cite web | url=http://www.scottisharchitects.org.uk/architect_full.php?id=200237 | title=William Landless | work=[[Dictionary of Scottish Architects]] | accessdate=28 February 2014}} The building was converted to Council offices in 1994–95. '''John Kelly''' went on to design several notable churches, including [[All Saints' Church, Petersham (London)|All Saints' Church, Petersham]]{{cite book | title=[[The Buildings of England]] – London 2: South | publisher=[[Penguin Books]] | author=[[Bridget Cherry|Cherry, Bridget]] and [[Nikolaus Pevsner|Pevsner, Nikolaus]]| year=1983 | location=London | page=514 | isbn=0-14-0710-47-7}} in the [[London Borough of Richmond upon Thames]] (Grade II listed, and now a private residence). Kelly's Roman Catholic churches, which also include [[St Agatha's Roman Catholic Church, Kingston upon Thames]] and [[Sacred Heart Church, Teddington]] in the London Borough of Richmond upon Thames,{{cite web |url=http://www.british-history.ac.uk/report.aspx?compid=22265 |title=Teddington: Roman catholicism |editor=[[Susan Reynolds|Reynolds, Susan]] |publisher=[[Institute of Historical Research]] |year=1962 |work=A History of the County of Middlesex: Volume 3: Shepperton, Staines, Stanwell, Sunbury, Teddington, Heston and Isleworth, Twickenham, Cowley, Cranford, West Drayton, Greenford, Hanwell, Harefield and Harlington |page = 79|accessdate=9 November 2014}}{{cite book | title=[[The Buildings of England]] – London 2: South | publisher=[[Penguin Books]] | author=[[Bridget Cherry|Cherry, Bridget]] and [[Nikolaus Pevsner|Pevsner, Nikolaus]] | year=1983 | location=London | page=535 | isbn=0-14-0710-47-7}}{{cite web|url=http://taking-stock.org.uk/Home/Dioceses/Archdiocese-of-Westminster/The-Sacred-Heart-Teddington |title=The Sacred Heart – Teddington |work = Taking Stock: Catholic Churches of England & Wales|accessdate=27 May 2015}} are all in a distinctive [[Italianate architecture|Italianate]] style, with [[Romanesque architecture|Romanesque]] features and some with large [[campanile]]. Towards the end of his career, Kelly was short-listed for, but failed to win, the contract for the [[Leeds Cathedral|Cathedral Church of St Anne's, Leeds]].{{cite web |url=http://taking-stock.org.uk/Home/Dioceses/Diocese-of-Leeds/Cathedral-Church-of-St-Anne-Leeds |title=Leeds – Cathedral Church of St Anne |work = Taking Stock: Catholic Churches of England & Wales|accessdate=27 May 2015}} Approaching retirement, Kelly established a new practice, ''John Kelly & Sons'', in [[Oxford Street]], London. The church of St Alban and St Stephen in [[St Albans]] dates from this time.{{cite web |url=http://taking-stock.org.uk/Home/Dioceses/Archdiocese-of-Westminster/St-Alban-and-St-Stephen-St-Albans| title=St Alban and St Stephen – St Albans |work = Taking Stock: Catholic Churches of England & Wales|accessdate=27 May 2015}} Following John Kelly's death in 1904, his son Claude Kelly took over the practice. The design of [[St Peter's Church, Aldrington]] in [[Hove]] (Grade II listed), attributed to Claude, is believed to have also been worked on by his father.{{National Heritage List for England |num=1209728|desc=St Peter's Church, Aldrington|accessdate=26 February 2014}} '''Edward Birchall''''s other work includes the country house Tylney Hall in [[Hampshire]], built in 1879, which is Grade II listed{{NHLE|num=1000176 |desc=Tylney Hall |accessdate=27 May 2015 }} and is now a hotel,{{cite web | url=http://www.tylneyhall.co.uk/history-tylney-hall | title=History | publisher=Tylney Hall Hotel | accessdate=13 September 2016}} and Carlton Hill [[Friends Meeting House]] (1868) which was the principal [[Quaker]] Meeting House in Leeds. Part of the building became a clothing factory in 1921, with the Quakers continuing to meet in a schoolroom at the back until 1979.{{cite web | url=http://openplaques.org/plaques/5140 | title=Carlton Hill Friends Meeting House | publisher=Open Heritage | work=Open Plaques | accessdate=19 April 2013}} The building was refurbished by [[Leeds Metropolitan University]] in 2007 and is now called [[BBC Yorkshire#Studios|Old Broadcasting House]].{{cite web | url=http://www.leedsquakers.org.uk/meetings/_c_hill-history | title=A short history of Leeds Quakers | publisher=Leeds Quakers | accessdate=19 April 2013}} It has a [[blue plaque]], erected by [[Leeds Civic Trust]], commemorating Birchall and the history of the building.{{cite web | url=http://www.blueplaqueplaces.co.uk/edward-birchall-blue-plaque-in-leeds-5140#.VwEcckdf1aQ | title=Edward Birchall blue plaque | publisher=[[Flikr]] | work=Carlton Hill Friends Meeting House | date=19 November 2010 | accessdate=3 April 2016 | author=Dalton, Ben}} ==Gallery== File:St Lukes church, Kingston-upon-Thames- south end (geograph 3442575).jpg|alt=St Lukes church, Kingston upon Thames- south end|[[St Luke's Church, Kingston upon Thames]] – south end, 1886–87 File:St Agnes, Burmantofts.jpg|alt=St Agnes, Burmantofts, Leeds|[[Burmantofts#History|St Agnes' Church, Burmantofts, Leeds, West Yorkshire, 1887–89]]{{cite web|url=http://www.stagnesunitedchurch.org/history--architecture.html|title=History and Architecture of St Agnes' Church|publisher=St Agnes' United Church, Leeds|accessdate=1 August 2016|author=Ullathorne, Alice}} File:St James' Church, Shireshead - geograph.org.uk - 615361.jpg|alt=St James' Church, Shireshead|St James' Church, [[Shireshead]], [[Lancashire]], 1887–90 File:Leeds Higher Grade School, Woodhouse Lane, Leeds - geograph.org.uk - 1383445.jpg|alt=Leeds Higher Grade School, Woodhouse Lane, Leeds|Leeds Higher Grade School, Woodhouse Lane, Leeds. {{other uses}} {{Infobox settlement |official_name = Khorramabad |native_name = خرم‌آباد |settlement_type = City |image_skyline = Khorramabad Mosaic 2.jpg |imagesize = 250px |image_caption = Montage of Khorramabad, Clockwise:[[Falak-ol-Aflak Castle]], [[Keeyow lake]], [[Shapuri bridge]], View of the Khorramabad city, [[Brick Minaret]], Panorama of the Khorramabad |image_seal =Khorramabad government logo.svg |pushpin_map = Iran |mapsize = 250px |image_map1 = Khorramabad-County.png |map_caption1 = The territory of the Khorramabad inside the province of Lorestan |subdivision_type = [[List of sovereign states|Country]] |subdivision_name = {{flag|Iran}} |subdivision_type1 = [[Provinces of Iran|Province]] |subdivision_name1 = [[Lorestan Province|Lorestan]] |subdivision_type2 = [[Counties of Iran|County]] |subdivision_name2 = [[Khorramabad County|Khorramabad]] |subdivision_type3 = [[Bakhsh]] |subdivision_name3 = [[Central District (Khorramabad County)|Central]] |leader_title = |leader_name = |established_title = |established_date = |area_total_km2 = |area_footnotes = |population_as_of = 2016 Census |population_urban = 373,416 <ref>https://www.amar.org.ir/english</ref> |population_metro = |population_est = |population_est_as_of = |population_density_km2 = auto |timezone = [[Iran Standard Time|IRST]] |utc_offset = +3:30 |timezone_DST = [[Iran Daylight Time|IRDT]] |utc_offset_DST = +4:30 |coordinates = {{coord|33|29|16|N|48|21|21|E|region:IR|display=inline,title}} |elevation_m = 1,147 |elevation_ft = 3,763 |area_code = |blank_name = [[Köppen climate classification|Climate]] |blank_info = [[Mediterranean climate#Hot-summer mediterranean climate|Csa]] |website = [http://www.khoramabad.ir/ www.Khorramabad.ir] |footnotes = }} '''Khorramabad''' {{pronunciation|Khorramabad.ogg}} ({{lang-fa|خرم‌آباد}} - also [[Romanize]]d as '''Khorramābād''', '''Khoramabad''', '''Khurramabad''', '''Khorram Abad''' and '''Khur Ramābād''')<ref>{{GEOnet3|-3071194}}</ref> is a city and capital of [[Lorestan Province]], [[Iran]]. At the time of the 2006 census, its population was 328,544, in 75,945 families.<ref>{{IranCensus2006|15}}</ref> Khorramabad is situated in the [[Zagros Mountains]]. [[Khorramabad Airport]] is 3 km south of the city proper.
The city population is predominantly [[Lurs|Lur]] and [[Lak people (Iran)|Lak]], although the two groups are closely related.<ref>Anonby, Erik John [http://anonby.balafon.net/wp-content/uploads/2007/06/jra-172-171-197.pdf "Update on Luri: How many languages"] ''JRAS (Journal of the Royal Asiatic Society) Series 3'' 13(2): pp. 171–197, p.183, {{doi|10.1017/S1356186303003067}}</ref> Although not a major tourist destination, it is quite scenic and possesses several attractions, such as five [[Paleolithic]] cave-dwelling sites.<ref>Baumler, Mark F. and Speth, John D. (1993) "A Middle Paleolithic Assemblage from Kunji Cave, Iran" pp. 1–74 ''In'' Olszewski, Deborah and Dibble, Harold Lewis (editors) (1993) ''The Paleolithic prehistory of the Zagros-Taurus'' The University Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology, University of Pennsylvania, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, {{ISBN|978-0-924171-24-6}}</ref> In the city center, a tall citadel called [[Falak-ol-Aflak]] (''The Heaven of Heavens''), a relic of the [[Sassanid]] era, is now a nationally popular museum.
Economically, it is the regional base of the [[agriculture|agricultural]] industry.
==History==
===Pre-Islamic era=== [[File:Susa-destruction.jpg|thumbnail|left|[[Elam]] and Khaydalu destruction by [[Assyrian people|Assyrians]]]]
====Khaydalu==== Khaydalu was an important city of the [[Elam]] civilization. The city of Shapurkhast was built on the ruins of Khaydalu on the orders of [[Shapur I]] [[Sasanid]]. Many experts believes that the ancient city of Khaydalu was the core of modern Khorramabad.
====Shapurkhast==== In the texts of historians Shapurkhast has been considered one of the most important and developed cities of the region during this period. [[Falak-ol-Aflak]] castle ( Dež-e Shāpūr-Khwāst) was built by [[Shapur I]] the [[Sasanid]].
===Islamic era=== Probably in the late seventh century CE, Shapurkhast was destroyed and the people of Shapurkhast moved to the western part of Falak-ol-Aflak Castle, which offered plenty of water as well as safety.
[[Hamdallah Mustawfi]] writes: Khorramabad was a beautiful city, now it is destroyed.
====Hazaraspids==== The founder of the Hazaraspid dynasty was [[Abu Tahir ibn Muhammad]], a descendant of the [[Shabankara]] chieftain [[Fadluya]]. Fadluya was initially a commander of the [[Salghurids]] of Fars and was appointed governor of [[Kohgiluyeh and Boyer-Ahmad Province|Kuhgiluya]]<ref>B. Spuller,[http://www.iranica.com/newsite/articles/unicode/v2f8/v2f8a075.html Atabakan-e Lorestan]{{dead link|date=December 2017 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }}, Encyclopædia Iranica.</ref> but eventually gained independence in [[Luristan]] and extended his realm as far as [[Isfahan]]. He assumed the prestigious title of ''[[atabeg]].
====Safavid dynasty==== During the reign of the [[Safavid dynasty]], Khorramabad was the administrative center of [[Luristan]] Province. In the wake of the demise of the Safavids, after the signing of the [[Treaty of Constantinople (1724)]] with [[Imperial Russia]], the [[Ottomans]] conquered Khorramabad on 6 September 1725.<ref>{{cite book|last1=Somel|first1=Selcuk Aksin|title=Historical Dictionary of the Ottoman Empire|date=2003|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=978-0810866065|page=xlvi|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jGZQL41tg_oC&pg=RA1-PR46&dq=ottomans+khoy&hl=nl&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwia9Zizp4nLAhUFkiwKHTtBCDYQ6AEIJDAB#v=onepage&q=ottomans%20khoy&f=false}}</ref> [[File:Xuramabad city.jpg|left|thumb|Khorramabad city - [[Luristan]]]]
====Qajar dynasty==== In this period, the city of Khorramabad was limited to environs of [[Falak-ol-Aflak Castle]].This period was the beginning of a migration of people from small villages into Khorramabad. The increase in population led to the expansion of the city and the creation of new districts.
====Pahlavi dynasty==== Khorramabad Municipality was formed in 1913 and the first city council, consisting of seven members, was formed in 1916. {{clearleft}}
== Geography and climate == Khorramabad has what is classed under the [[Köppen climate classification]] as a [[semi-arid]] (''BSh'') climate with continental influences, owing to its high altitude making it much wetter than lowland cities like Baghdad or cities more shielded from the [[Zagros Mountains]] like [[Esfahan]] and [[Tehran]]. It remains extremely hot in the summer even with very low humidity, but the winter is sufficiently wet for rainfed agriculture.

== Main sights ==
=== Falak-ol-Aflak Castle === [[File:Falak ol aflak night.jpg|thumbnail|[[Falak-ol-Aflak Castle]]]] [[Falak-ol-Aflak Castle]], Dež-e Shāpūr-Khwāst, Falak-ol-Aflak Castle, known in ancient times as Dezbaz as well as Shapur-Khast, is one of the most impressive castles in Iran. It is situated on the top of a large hill with the same name within the city of Khorramabad, the regional capital of Lorestan province. The Khorramabad River runs past the eastern and south-western side of the Falak-ol-Aflak hill providing the fortress with an element of natural protection. Today, the western and northern sides of the hill are bordered by the residential districts of Khorramabad. This gigantic structure was built during the [[Sassanid era]] (226–651). It has been known by a number of names since it was built over 1800 years ago. Recorded names have referred to it as Shapur-Khast or Sabr-Khast fortress, Dezbaz, Khorramabad castle, and ultimately the Falak ol-Aflak Castle. The foundations of the actual castle measure approximately 300 meters by 400 meters. The height of the entire structure, including the hill, reaches up to 40 meters above the surrounding area. This space is divided into four large halls, and their associated rooms and corridors. The rooms all surround two courtyards with the following measurements: the first courtyard measures 31×22.50 meters and the second 29x21 meters. . When originally built the castle used to have 12 towers, but only 8 remain standing today. The building's entrance is situated towards the north, within the body of the north-western tower. {{wide image|Khorramabad pan 2014 night.jpg|1200px|Panorama of Khorramabad and [[Falak-ol-Aflak Castle|Falak-ol-aflak]] castle in the middle.}}
=== Gerdab sangi === [[Gerdab Sangi]] is located in Takhti Square in Khorramabad, Lorestan and is made of stones and plaster. It dates back to the Sassanid era (224-651 CE) and is a circular whirlpool built for the purpose of accurate and optimal distribution of water. Encircling several springs, the edifice sits near the prehistoric Qomri Cave. The construction was once used for rationing and distributing potable and agricultural water among local population and farmers. Its surrounding cylindrical stone wall has a height of 10 meters and a diameter of 18 meters. There are a few different-sized outlets in the wall for controlling the flow of water into a canal on the west of the structure. While originally there were 7 of such outlets, however, today only one is functional. This outlet measures 160 x 90 centimeters and opens and closes like a drawer. The water flowing out of this outlet, after a path of approximately 12 kilometers, would eventually make its way to a valley called Baba Abbas. In the vicinity of this valley, and the location of the ancient city of Shapurkhast, the remnants of an old mill, which was run using water from the springs, can be observed. Gerdab Sangi was registered on the National Heritage List in 1976.
=== Brick minaret === [[Brick Minaret]] is a 900-year-old brick tower located beside the ancient city of Shapur khawst, south of Khorramabad, Lorestan province. It was built as a guidepost for caravans in ancient times. The minaret is about 30 meters tall with a circumference of 17.5 meters. Inside the tower there is a spiral staircase of 99 stairs.
=== Inscribed stone === In a stone-edged circle beside thundering Shari’ati St is an inscribed stone from around AD 1150, apparently setting out details of local grazing rights.
=== Shapoori bridge === [[File:(پل شکسته (پل شاپوری.jpg|thumbnail|[[Shapoori Bridge]]]]
[[Shapoori Bridge]] is located in southern KhorramAbad. It has been used to connect the western part of [[Lorestan]] ([[Tarhan District|Tarhan]]) to the east, and then on to Khoozestan province and Taysafun, the capital city of the Sassanian. The bridge is 312 meters long and 10.75 meters high. It has 28 arches and 27 piles. The area of each pile is 61 square meters, and the distance between the two piles is 7.5 meters. Five of its arches are intact; the others have been destroyed by natural factors. The arches of the bridge are made in the form of a wishbone. The piles and breakwaters of the bridge are in the form of six lateral lozenges made of stone. Probably the bridge also was used to distribute water. Materials of the bridge are river stones and stone chips in the arches and truncated stones in the piles. The bridge floor is paved in red block stones that have lost their square shape due to erosion. This attractive, huge bridge belongs to Sassanian era, and it is registered as number 1058 in the list of Iranian national monuments.
=== Akhoond Aboo house === [[Akhoond Aboo house]] is located in the west of Falak-ol-Aflak Castle, in Khorramabad.
=== Keeyow lake === [[Keeyow lake]] is a natural lake located in the Northwest of Khorramabad. This lake spans a seven-hectare area and has a depth of 3 to 7 meters. There is an amusement park as well as other recreational facilities next to this lake. Keeyow lake, which is the only natural city lake in Iran, is a habitat for native and migratory Birds and Aquatic animals.<ref>{{cite web|title=دریاچه کیو خرم‌آباد تنها دریاچه طبیعی درون‌شهری ایران|url=http://www.yjc.ir/fa/news/5543425/%D8%AF%D8%B1%DB%8C%D8%A7%DA%86%D9%87-%DA%A9%DB%8C%D9%88-%D8%AE%D8%B1%D9%85-%D8%A2%D8%A8%D8%A7%D8%AF-%D8%AA%D9%86%D9%87%D8%A7-%D8%AF%D8%B1%DB%8C%D8%A7%DA%86%D9%87-%D8%B7%D8%A8%DB%8C%D8%B9%DB%8C-%D8%AF%D8%B1%D9%88%D9%86-%D8%B4%D9%87%D8%B1%DB%8C-%D8%A7%DB%8C%D8%B1%D8%A7%D9%86-%D8%AA%D8%B5%D8%A7%D9%88%DB%8C%D8%B1|publisher=Young Jouranalists Club|accessdate=29 October 2017}}</ref>
{{wide image|Kiau Lake Panorama Reza.jpg|900px|Panorama of Keeyow lake located in the Northwest of Khorramabad}}
==Colleges and universities== [[File:Islamic Azad University of Khorramabad 01.jpg|thumb|Islamic Azad University of Khorramabad]] *[[Islamic Azad University of Khorram Abad]] *[[Lorestan University]]<ref>[http://www.lu.ac.ir/English/English.htm Lorestan University" homepage, in English] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100920214046/http://www.lu.ac.ir/English/English.htm |date=September 20, 2010 }}</ref> *[[Lorestan University of Medical Sciences]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.lums.ac.ir/ |title=Lorestan University of Medical Sciences homepage |publisher=Lums.ac.ir |date= |accessdate=2012-09-12}}</ref> *[[Madanni Technical College]]<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.afpkh.ir/ |title=afpkh.ir |publisher=afpkh.ir |date= |accessdate=2012-09-12 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120911083121/http://www.afpkh.ir/ |archivedate=2012-09-11 |df= }}</ref>

revision.comment: Corrected birth year of Barbara Morgan
revision.text:
[[File:Light Painting Urbex.jpg|thumb|upright=1.5| Lightpainting inside an abandoned limestone quarry in [[France]]]]
'''Light painting, painting with light,''' '''light drawing''', or '''light art performance photography''' are terms that describe [[photography|photographic]] techniques of moving a light source while taking a [[long exposure]] photograph, either to illuminate a subject or space, or to shine light at the [[camera]] to 'draw', or by moving the camera itself during exposure of light sources. Practised since the 1880s, the technique is used for both scientific and artistic purposes, as well as in commercial photography.
== History ==
Light painting (also called light drawing) dates back to 1889 when [[Étienne-Jules Marey]] and [[Georges Demenÿ|Georges Demeny]] traced human motion in the first known light painting ''Pathological Walk From in Front''.<ref name="lightphoto">{{cite web |title=History |url=http://lightpaintingphotography.com/light-painting-history/ |website=Light Painting Photography}}</ref>
The technique was used in [[Frank Gilbreth]]'s work with his wife [[Lillian Moller Gilbreth]] in 1914, when the pair used small lights and the open shutter of a camera to track the motion of manufacturing and clerical workers.
[[Man Ray]], in his 1935 series "Space Writing," was the first known art photographer to use the technique. He made a self-portrait with a time exposure and while the shutter was open, with a penlight he inscribed his name in cursive script in the space between him and the camera, overwriting the letters with more cryptic marks.<ref>Foresta, M. (1991). Tracing the Line: Art and Photography in the Age of Contact. Aperture (Archive : 1952-2005) (125), 16-23.</ref><ref>{{cite book | author1=Anne Collins Goodyear | author2=Jonathan Frederick Walz | author3=Kathleen Merrill Campagnolo |others=Contribution by Dorinda Evans | title=This is a portrait if I say so : identity in American art, 1912 to today | publication-date=2016 | publisher=[[Bowdoin College Museum of Art]] in association with [[Yale University Press]] | oclc=989165304 | isbn=978-0-300-21193-1 }}</ref> Historian of photography Ellen Carey (*1952) describes her discovery of the artist's signature in this image while examining it in 2009.<ref>{{cite magazine |last=Carey |first=Ellen |date=Fall 2011 |title=At Play With Man Ray |url=http://www.ellencareyphotography.com/pictus-writ-man-ray/ |magazine=Aperture |issue=204 |page=77 }}</ref>
[[File:Pure Energy and Neurotic Man 1940.jpg|thumb|right|''Pure Energy and Neurotic Man,'' a light painting by [[Barbara Morgan (photographer)|Barbara Morgan]] (1940)]] Photographer [[Barbara Morgan (photographer)|Barbara Morgan]] began making light paintings in 1935-1941.<ref>Franks, Elizabeth Ellen. “Capturing Motion: A Catalog Raisonné of the Photomontage Works of Barbara Morgan 1935-1980.” MA Thesis, University of California Riverside, 2013.</ref> Her 1941 photomontage ''Pure Energy and Neurotic Man'' incorporates light drawing and realises her stated aim; "that if I should ever seriously photograph, it would be...the flux of things. I wanted then, and still do, to express the ‘thing’ as part of total flow."<ref>Morgan, Barbara, and Marianne F. Margolis. Barbara Morgan: Photomontage. Dobbs Ferry, N.Y: Morgan & Morgan, 1980</ref> In making innovative photographs of dancers, including [[Martha Graham]] and [[Erick Hawkins]] she would have them move while holding lights.
In 1949 [[Pablo Picasso]] was visited by [[Gjon Mili]], a photographer and lighting innovator, who introduced Picasso to his photographs of ice skaters with lights attached to their skates. Immediately Picasso started making images in the air with a small flashlight in a dark room. This series of photos became known as Picasso's "light drawings." Of these photos, the most celebrated and famous is known as ''Picasso draws a Centaur''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.vpphotogallery.com/photog_mili_picasso.htm |title="Pablo Picasso" by Gjon Mili |publisher=VP Gallery |accessdate=2008-12-23 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090126215646/http://www.vpphotogallery.com/photog_mili_picasso.htm |archivedate=2009-01-26 |df= }}</ref>
Peter Keetman (1916–2005), who studied photography in [[Munich]] from 1935 to 1937, was the 1949 co-founder of [[Fotoform|FotoForm]] (together with [[Otto Steinert]], Toni Schneiders et al.), a group with great impact on the new photography in the 50s and 60s in Germany and abroad. He produced a series ''Schwingungsfigur'' (oscillating figures) of complex linear meshes, often with moiré effects, using a point-source light on a pendulum.<ref>{{cite book | author1=Jäger, Gottfried | author2=Reese, Beate | author3=Krauss, Rolf H | title=Concrete photography = Konkrete fotografie | publication-date=2005 | publisher=Kerber Verlag | isbn=978-3-936646-74-0 }}</ref>
During the 1970s and 80's [[Eric Staller]]<ref>[http://ericstaller.com/studio%20work/light%20drawings/ Eric Staller - Light Drawings]</ref> used this technology for numerous photo projects that were called "Light Drawings". Light paintings up to 1976 are classified as light drawings.{{Citation needed|date=September 2016}}
In 1977 [[Dean Chamberlain]] extended the technique using handheld lights to selectively illuminate and/or colour parts of the subject or scene with his image ''Polyethylene Bags On Chaise Longue'' at The [[Rochester Institute of Technology]]. Dean Chamberlain was the first artist to dedicate his entire body of work to the light painting art form.<ref name="lightphoto" /> The artist photographer [[Jacques Pugin]] made several series of images with the light drawing technique in 1979.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://lpwalliance.com/index2.php?type=publicationview&id=41 |title=Light Painting Historical Catalogue (part two) |website=[[Light Painting World Alliance]] (LPWA)}}</ref> Now, with modern light painting, one uses more frequently choreography and performance to photograph and organize.
[[File:SittingWaveTwoCycles.gif|thumb|Photograph of an electromagnetic radio wave with S.W.I.M. (Sequential Wave Imprinting Machine), which captures traveling waves in stationary spacetime coordinates (i.e. as a "sitting wave")<ref>{{cite conference |title=Surveillance (Oversight), Sousveillance (Undersight), and Metaveillance (Seeing Sight Itself) |author=Steve Mann |book-title=The IEEE Conference on Computer Vision and Pattern Recognition (CVPR) Workshops |publisher=IEEE |year=2016 |pages=1-10 |url=https://www.cv-foundation.org//openaccess/content_cvpr_2016_workshops/w29/papers/Mann_Surveillance_Oversight_Sousveillance_CVPR_2016_paper.pdf }}</ref>]] In the 1970s and early 1980s, [[Steve Mann]] invented, designed, built, and used various wearable computers to visualize real-world phenomena such as sound waves, radio waves, and sight fields by light painting using computational photography.<ref>Campus Canada, {{ISSN|0823-4531}}: p. 55, Feb-Mar 1985; pp. 58-59, Apr-May 1986; and p. 72, Sep-Oct 1986.</ref><ref>Impulse, {{ISSN|0315-3649}}, Volume 12, Number 2, 1985</ref><ref>Mann, S. (1997). Wearable computing: A first step toward personal imaging. IEEE Computer, 30(2), pp. 25-32.</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last=Godshaw |first=Reid |year=2016 |title=The Art and Science of Light Painting |journal=The STEAM Journal |volume=2 |issue=2 |at=Article 23 |doi=10.5642/steam.20160202.23 |url=http://scholarship.claremont.edu/steam/vol2/iss2/23}}</ref>
Since the 1980s, [[Vicki DaSilva]] has been working exclusively in light painting and light graffiti.<ref>{{cite book|last=McRee |first=Claire |date=2016 |title=Allentown X7 Photographic Explorations |publisher=Allentown Art Museum of the Lehigh Valley |chapter=The Multivalent Subject: Photographic Approaches to Allentown |isbn=978-1-882011-65-0}}</ref> In 1980, DaSilva<ref>[http://www.vickidasilva.com/ Vicki DaSilva]</ref> started making deliberate text light graffiti works, the first being "Cash".<ref>[http://www.vickidasilva.com/light-gra/ Vicki DaSilva - Light Graffiti]</ref> She continued these light graffiti photographs throughout the 1980s and eventually started using 4 foot fluorescent bulbs hooked up to pulley systems to create sheets of light. In the early 2000s she began making work with 8 foot fluorescent lamps, holding the lamp vertically and walking through spaces with it.<ref>[http://www.vickidasilva.com/interiors/ Vicki DaSilva - Light Painting - Interiors]</ref><ref>[http://www.vickidasilva.com/exteriors/ Vicki DaSilva - Light Painting - Exteriors]</ref>
From the late 1980s [[Tokihiro Satō]]'s photographs combine light, time and space in recording his movements in a series beginning with his “photo respirations” where his use of an 8 x 10-inch [[view camera]] fitted with a strong [[neutral-density filter]] to achieve lengthy exposures lasting one to three hours provide the opportunity for him to move through the landscape.<ref>{{Cite book | author1=Satō, Tokihiro | author2=Siegel, Elizabeth | title=Photo respiration : Tokihiro Sato photographs | publication-date=2005 | publisher=Art Institute of Chicago | location=Chicago | edition= 1st | oclc=718345388 | isbn=978-0-86559-217-9 }}</ref> When shooting in daylight, with a mirror he flashed light from the sun into the camera lens, resulting in points of light and flares that punctuate the image and track his movements, though his presence is not seen directly. For nocturnal or interior views he “draws” with a small torch.
[[File:SuperNaturalBreakdancer.jpg|thumb|Light art performance photography: ''Natural Breakdancer'']] [[File:BlueMystery2.jpg|thumb|Light art performance photography: ''Blue Mystery'']]
Light painting as an artform enjoyed a surge in popularity in the 21st century, partly due to the increasing availability of [[dSLR]] cameras and [[Camera phone|mobile phone cameras]] enabling immediate feedback for adjustments of lights and exposure; advances in portable light sources such as LEDs; and the advent of media sharing websites by which practitioners can exchange images and ideas.
In March 2007, [[JanLeonardo]] coined the term ''light art performance photography (LAPP)''<ref name=":0">JanLeonardo Woellert & Joerg Miedza - Faszination Lichtmalerei: Die Kunst der Light Art Performance Photography, 09/2010, dpunkt Verlag, {{ISBN|978-3-89864-669-7}} (German)</ref> which emphasises the performative aspect that is evident earlier in [[Tokihiro Satō|Satō]]'s work,<ref>Anonymous. (2016). IN TERMS OF ART. Art and AsiaPacific (100), 98-109.</ref> and used it to describe the creation of new figures and structures only with light. Following the original [[Ancient Greek|Greek]] meaning of [[Photography]] (Greek φῶς, phos, genetive: φωτός, photos, "light" (of the luminary), "brightness" and γράφειν, graphein, "drawing", "carve", "create", "write") it is a [[symbiosis]] of [[light art]] and photography. The main difference from other ''light painting'' or ''light writing'', it has been claimed,<ref name=":0" /> is the role of the background in the photo.{{Clarify|clarification needed=|date=July 2018}} Locations in the natural landscape or amongst buildings, such as industrial ruins, are carefully researched for distinctive backgrounds for each composition and [[LED]]-lamps are often used for contrasting cold and warm light to emphasise the existing structures. Collaboration is usually required in the performance of the work, with one person creating light figures and structures while the other operates the camera. In collaboration with Jörg Miedza, JanLeonardo founded the project LAPP-PRO.de that further developed the technique until in 2011, the pair disassociated. LAPP has grown internationally since its inception.<ref>{{cite web |title=Interview |url=http://cpn.canon-europe.com/content/interviews/light_art_performance_photography.do |date=February 2009 |website=Canon Professionell Network |publisher=Canon}}</ref><ref name=":0"/>
== Techniques == [[File:Light painting screw.jpg|thumb|right|''Light Painting Screw'', by Karsten Knöfler]] Light painting using handheld lights to selectively illuminate or colour parts of the subject or scene or to evenly light large architectural interiors has been used in professional photography since the 1930s as described by Leslie Walker<ref>{{cite book | author1=Walker, Leslie C | title=The technique of painting with light | publication-date=1940 | publisher=The Nash-Jones publishing company | url=http://trove.nla.gov.au/work/32824743 | accessdate=17 March 2016 }}</ref> and [[Ansel Adams]].<ref>{{cite book | author1=Adams, Ansel | author2=Baker, Robert | publisher=New York Graphic Society | title=The negative | publication-date=1981 | edition= 1st | page= 174| isbn=978-0-8212-1131-1 }}</ref> Light painting requires a slow [[shutter speed]], usually at least a second in duration. Light painting can imitate characteristics of traditional painting; superimposition and transparency can easily be achieved by moving, adding or removing lights or subjects during or between exposures.
Projector light painting, by waving a white translucent flash diffuser in the light path of a portable projector, the continuous motion creates a invisible screen in air for the projected image in the photo.
Light paintings can be created using a [[webcam]].{{Clarify|clarification needed=|date=March 2016}} The painted image can already be seen while drawing by using a monitor or projector. Another technique is the projection of images on to irregular surfaces (such as faces or buildings), in effect "painting" them with light. A photograph or other fixed portrayal of the resulting image is then made.
Kinetic light painting is achieved by moving the camera, and is the antithesis of traditional photography. At night, or in a dark room, the camera can be removed from the tripod and used like a [[paintbrush]]. An example is using the night sky as the canvas, the camera as the brush and artificially-lit cityscapes as the palette. Putting energy into moving the camera by stroking lights,{{clarify|date=October 2014}} making patterns and laying down backgrounds can create abstract artistic images.
== Equipment == [[File:Wikimedia-2306.jpg|thumb|Light art performance photography: laser, LED and long time shot]] A variety of light sources can be used, ranging from simple [[flashlight]]s to dedicated devices like the Hosemaster, which uses a [[fiber optic]] light pen.<ref>{{cite web | url=http://photo.net/learn/studio/primer | title=Studio Photography | first=Philip | last=Greenspun | date=January 2007 | publisher=Photo.net | accessdate=2007-09-26 | deadurl=yes | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070929104533/http://photo.net/learn/studio/primer | archivedate=2007-09-29 | df= }}</ref> Other sources of light including candles, matches, fireworks, lighter flints, [[glowsticks]], and [[Poi (juggling)|poi]] are also popular.
A [[tripod (photography)|tripod]] is usually necessary due to the long exposure times involved. Alternatively, the camera may be placed on or braced against a table or other solid support. A [[Bulb (photography)|shutter release cable]] or [[self timer]] is generally employed in order to minimize camera shake. [[Color gel]]s can also be used to color the light sources.
Some light painters make their own dedicated devices to create light trails over the photo background; this can include computer-controlled devices like the Pixelstick. These devices are often Arduino-controlled LED arrays that can render images that could not be made by drawing in the air with a single light source alone. LED lights, [[Luminescence|luminescent]] materials, [[pyrotechnics]], [[fireworks]] and [[flashlight]]s are also used.
== Important artists == {{div col|colwidth=16em}} * [[Vicki DaSilva]] (born 1960) * [[Jack Delano]] (1914–1997) * [[Andreas Feininger]] (1906–1999) * [[JanLeonardo]] (born 1970) * [[Georges Mathieu]] (1921–2012) * [[Gjon Mili]] (1904–1984) * [[Pablo Picasso]] (1881–1973) * [[Man Ray]] (1890–1976) * [[Eric Staller]] (born 1947) *[[Barbara Morgan]] (born 1951) {{div col end}}
==Awards and recognition== * Deutscher Preis für Wissenschaftsfotografie 2008 – 1. Platz<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.archiv.fraunhofer.de/archiv/magazin04-08/fhg/Images/Magazin1-2009_42_tcm5-108597.pdf|title=Deutscher Preis für Wissenschaftsfotografie 2008 – 1. Platz|accessdate=18 November 2014|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20141227223902/http://www.archiv.fraunhofer.de/archiv/magazin04-08/fhg/Images/Magazin1-2009_42_tcm5-108597.pdf|archivedate=27 December 2014|df=}}</ref>{{verification needed|date=August 2018}}
== See also == {{div col|colwidth=15em}} * [[Available light]] * [[Fire dancing]] * [[Glowsticking]] * [[Kinetic photography]] * [[Light art]] * [[Night photography]] {{div col end}}
== References == {{reflist|33em}}
==Further reading== * {{cite book |author1=JanLeonardo Woellert |author2=Joerg Miedza |last-author-amp=yes |title=Painting with Light: Light Art Performance Photography |year=2011 |publisher=Rocky Nook |edition=English |isbn=978-1-9339-5274-1}}
== External links == {{Commons}} <!-- The links in this section should add to the article and be informative. Do not add links to mere photo galleries, they will be removed. See [[WP:EL]] about what links are ok, and what aren't. --> * [http://www.amateurphotographer.co.uk/how-to/photo-techniques/539651/light-painting-masterclass-with-michael-bosanko Article in ''Amateur Photographer'' magazine on the fundamental basics of Light Painting] * [http://www.michaelbosanko.com/light-sculptures-light-graffiti Diverse light painting techniques by Michael Bosanko] * [http://lpwalliance.com Light Painting World Alliance - non-profit organization united all light painters in the globe] * [http://lpwalliance.com/index2.php?type=publicationview&id=15 Painting with Light - How it all began - Historical article about light painting's roots] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20131206034620/http://life.time.com/culture/pablo-picasso-draws-with-light-1949/ Life Magazine - Behind the Photograph - about Pablo Picasso as he paints with light] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20151002013634/http://psy.in/ various style of natural light sources - Moon, stars, fire] * [http://www.lp-award.com/ International Light Painting Award | Bi-Annual, International Photo Competition For Light Painting] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20140915050745/http://www.lightart-photography.de/attachments/20/52rZpqsm6ZfnVK86/Diplom_Arbeit_Lydia_Mantler_LAPP_LightPainting-pdf Thesis from Dipl-Ing Lydia Mantler about Light Painting in particular about LAPP (German)] * [http://www.lapp-pro.de Official LAPP Homepage (German-English)] * [http://www.fotocommunity.de/pc/pc/channel/5/cat/14381 Fotocommunity - LAPP section (German)] * [http://augenblicke.t-online.de/c/17/49/09/84/17490984,pt=self,si=11.html t-online Fotomagazin - LAPP Lichtkunst (German)] * [http://www.dailymail.co.uk/sciencetech/article-1210538/Pictured-The-incredible-light-graffiti-created-host-light-sources-shine-straight-camera-lens.html ''Daily Mail'' article about LAPP and the developer (English)] * [http://cpn.canon-europe.com/content/interviews/light_art_performance_photography.do Canon article about LAPP (English)] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20141102130118/http://www.profifoto.de/aktuelle-ausgabe/artikelarchiv/311-lapp/ ProfiFoto Article about LAPP (German)] * [https://www.flickr.com/groups/lapp/ Flickr LAPP Group (English)] * [http://www.lp-award.com/ International Light Painting Award | Annual, International Photo Competition For Light Painting] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20101023054323/http://swiss-lapp.ch/ SWISS LAPP website (English / German)] <!-- The links in this section should add to the article and be informative. Do not add links to mere photo galleries, they will be removed. See [[WP:EL]] about what links are ok, and what aren't. -->
